nodes.name: Advanced semiconductor supply disruption impacting AI development
aliases: AI hardware bottleneck from semiconductor disruption
nodes.description: Loss or delay of advanced chips would stall training and deployment of cutting-edge AI systems, creating strategic and safety risks.
nodes.node_rationale: Central risk highlighted throughout the issue brief introduction and executive summary.

nodes.name: Geographical concentration of leading-edge foundry capacity in Taiwan
nodes.description: TSMC alone holds 54 % of the global logic foundry market, especially for <7 nm nodes, localising production risk in one region.
nodes.node_rationale: Derived from report section ‘Foundry market share’; explains a major cause of supply fragility.

nodes.name: Monopoly on EUV lithography equipment in Netherlands
nodes.description: ASML (Netherlands) is the sole producer of extreme-ultraviolet scanners, indispensable for 5 nm and below process nodes.
nodes.node_rationale: Presented in ‘Equipment chokepoints’ table as a key single-country bottleneck.

nodes.name: Monopoly on full-spectrum EDA software in United States
nodes.description: Synopsys, Cadence and Mentor (US) provide the entire tool-chain required for chip design, giving the US leverage over global design.
nodes.node_rationale: Outlined in report section ‘Design and IP core segment’ as an upstream choke-point.

nodes.name: Complex multistep semiconductor supply chain systemic fragility
nodes.description: Producing a chip involves >1 000 process steps crossing 70+ borders, so any choke-point failure cascades globally.
nodes.node_rationale: Explicitly quantified in report overview, framing the systemic nature of the risk.

nodes.name: Tacit manufacturing know-how barrier to latecomer entry in semiconductor production
nodes.description: Advanced fabs require extensive tacit expertise accumulated over decades, limiting rapid replication by new entrants.
nodes.node_rationale: Discussed under ‘300 mm wafer fabrication know-how’; justifies why monopolies persist.

nodes.name: Strategic diversification of semiconductor supply chain among allies
nodes.description: Spreading critical manufacturing stages across multiple allied jurisdictions reduces single-point failure risk.
nodes.node_rationale: Common policy inference drawn in report conclusion discussing ally strengths vs Chinese positions.

nodes.name: Restricting adversary access to critical semiconductor tools to maintain advantage
nodes.description: Limiting rivals’ procurement of crucial equipment or software preserves relative capability and slows proliferation.
nodes.node_rationale: Referenced implicitly in export-control discussion sections.

nodes.name: Government subsidies and incentives for domestic leading-edge fabs
nodes.description: Direct grants, tax credits and long-term purchase guarantees lower the $10–20 B capital barrier to new advanced fabs.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanism seen in CHIPS-style proposals alluded to in ‘Policy implications’ paragraph.

nodes.name: Export controls on EUV and ArF immersion scanners
nodes.description: Licence requirements preventing shipment of cutting-edge lithography tools to specified foreign fabs.
nodes.node_rationale: Cited in report’s note on Netherlands/Japan monopoly and US pressure to restrict exports.

nodes.name: Allied cooperation agreements for secure semiconductor raw material supply
nodes.description: Formal arrangements among US, Japan, EU etc. to share reserves and coordinate stockpiles of silicon, gallium, tungsten, magnesium.
nodes.node_rationale: Suggested by material-supply tables comparing allied reserves vs Chinese production.

nodes.name: TSMC 54% foundry share with rising revenue per wafer
nodes.description: Empirical data show TSMC’s dominant and growing profitability, evidencing concentration and pricing power.
nodes.node_rationale: From ‘Foundry revenue trends’ figure; used to justify subsidy urgency.

nodes.name: Netherlands and Japan equipment market monopolies data
nodes.description: Market-share tables show ASML (NL) and Nikon-Canon (JP) controlling EUV and ArF immersion markets respectively.
nodes.node_rationale: Validates feasibility of export-control leverage.

nodes.name: US 39% global semiconductor value share due to EDA leadership
nodes.description: Value-added analysis attributes 39 % of global chain to US, primarily through IP and EDA tools.
nodes.node_rationale: Supports continued leverage via software export regimes.

nodes.name: China controls two-thirds of global silicon production data
nodes.description: Report’s materials table shows ~66 % silicon output from China, demonstrating a supply vulnerability.
nodes.node_rationale: Quantitative backing for allied raw-material agreements.

nodes.name: Chinese dominance in key semiconductor raw materials
nodes.description: China leads production of silicon, low-grade gallium, tungsten and magnesium, posing concentration risk.
nodes.node_rationale: Problem framed in ‘Materials segment’ section.

nodes.name: Allied reserves can buffer raw material supply risk
nodes.description: Despite Chinese production dominance, allies possess significant untapped reserves, allowing mitigation via coordination.
nodes.node_rationale: Inference drawn in report commentary comparing production to reserve data.

nodes.name: Provide large-scale subsidies to build domestic leading-edge semiconductor fabrication plants
nodes.description: Allocate multi-billion-dollar grants, tax credits and guaranteed purchase contracts to firms constructing <7 nm fabs within allied territory.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Applies to manufacturing phase; maps to ‘Other’ (national industrial policy). Source: conclusions discussing competitiveness.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Legislation (e.g., US CHIPS Act) passed but large-scale fabs still under construction – prototype/pilot stage.
nodes.node_rationale: Direct actionable policy option widely discussed in context of report’s findings.

nodes.name: Enforce export controls on EUV and ArF immersion scanners to adversary nations
nodes.description: Coordinate with Dutch and Japanese governments to withhold licences for shipping latest-generation scanners to designated foreign fabs.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Policy instrument active during manufacturing equipment acquisition phase.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Operational—licence denials already enacted for multiple Chinese fabs.
nodes.node_rationale: Key intervention logically flowing from equipment monopoly evidence.

nodes.name: Form multilateral agreements securing semiconductor raw materials among allies
nodes.description: Negotiate treaties for shared stockpiles, coordinated extraction and emergency sharing of silicon, gallium, tungsten and magnesium.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Cross-border policy implemented outside model life-cycle phases.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Early diplomatic discussions, few formal treaties—experimental stage.
nodes.node_rationale: Actionable response to raw-material concentration highlighted by report.

nodes.name: Export controls on full-spectrum EDA software
nodes.description: Licence requirements limiting access to comprehensive chip design tool-chains.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanism inferred from US value-share and prior precedent of adding EDA tools to Commerce control lists.

nodes.name: Enforce export licensing restrictions on advanced EDA software to adversary nations
nodes.description: Mandate Commerce licence approvals for overseas access to state-of-the-art logic synthesis, place & route, verification suites.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Applies during design phase procurement, mapped to policy (Other).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Initial regulations enacted; efficacy assessments ongoing—prototype policy stage.
nodes.node_rationale: Completes causal chain from EDA monopoly evidence.
